prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 4
Name: Odie Asman
Description: The man who perished in the explosion on the experimentation stage at the Great Exhibition of London.↳The man who perished in the explosion on the experimentation stage. He was Professor Harebrayne's financial backer and the boss of a large criminal organisation.
Character 5
Name: Albert Harebrayne
Description: A scientist who invented a machine to demonstrate super-high-voltage instantaneous kinesis. However, it exploded in use, and he is now accused of murder.↳A scientist who invented a machine to demonstrate super-high-voltage instantaneous kinesis. He's the defendant of this case and a friend to Lord van Zieks, apparently.
Character 6
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 7
Name: Masked Man
Description: An apprentice of Lord van Zieks whose face is always covered by a mask. He has the air of a completely unassailable man.
Character 8
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A mostly reformed pickpocket who's now a self-appointed 'detective inspector'. She's really making waves in her new apprenticeship.
Character 9
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 10
Name: Esmeralda Tusspells
Description: The proprietress of the Madame Tusspells Museum of Waxwork and the latest in a line of artisans privy to the secret Tusspells technique of capturing a perfect likeness.
Character 11
Name: Balthazar Lune
Description: The impresario of short pleasure voyages in flying balloons. The balloons above the experimentation state all belonged to this man.
Character 12
Name: Bohemian Boy
Description: A young boy who came to London to visit the Great Exhibition. His real name is Wilhelm Gottsreich Sigismond Ormstein.↳A young prince from the royal family of Bohemia with an excessively long name. He witnessed the explosion at the Great Exhibition.
Character 13
Name: Courtney Sithe
Description: Scotland Yard coroner, leader of the Forensic Investigation Team and one of Lord Stronghart's most trusted allies.
Character 14
Name: Enoch Drebber
Description: A trickster who seems to be both an engineer and a magician. He constructed the machine for Professor Harebrayne's demonstration.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Great Exhibition Newspaper
Description: A newspaper containing various articles about the world-leading science and technology on show at the Great Exhibition being held in London.
Evidence 2
Name: Experiment Sketch
Description: A diagram showing the relative positions of the Crystal Tower and Professor Harebrayne's machine that exploded. 
Evidence 3
Name: Mysterious Contraption → Crossbow
Description: A very curious device found behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds, almost as if it had been hidden there deliberately. A weapon found hidden behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. It turns out that it's a folding crossbow. A crossbow found hidden behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. It belongs to Mr Enoch Drebber.
Evidence 4
Name: Piece of Green Cloth
Description: A torn piece of canvas-like material backed with rubber that was found under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. There are scorch marks at the edges.
Evidence 5
Name: Photograph of the Victim
Description: A photographic print of the victim taken after he had ostensibly been 'beamed' to the Crystal Tower. It shows an apparent stab wound to the chest.
Evidence 6
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the victim, Mr Asman. His neck was broken from the impact of a violent fall and he was stabbed in the chest with a sharp object.
Evidence 7
Name: Screwdriver
Description: Professor Harebrayne's trusty screwdriver that he's named 'Andrew'. There are traces of blood at the tip and it matches the shape of the victim's wound. A metal screwdriver that was found poking through the grille in the base of what remains of the kinesis machine. It has a very distinctive handle.
Evidence 8
Name: Photograph of the Balloon
Description: A photograph taken by Gotts whilst he was riding in a balloon. It shows another balloon that he claims was green and exploded moments after he took this shot.
Evidence 9
Name: Drebber's Card
Description: Mr Enoch Drebber's business card, though it shows only the man's name. There is no address. Mr Enoch Drebber's business card, which lists no address for the man. There is a smear of machine oil on the reverse.
Evidence 10
Name: Wooden 'Birdcage'
Description: The wooden cage that was used for Professor Harebrayne's experiment. This cage, with the victim inside, crashed down into the Crystal Tower. The wooden cage that was used for the demonstration. It crashed down, with the victim inside, into the Crystal Tower causing damage to its base.
Evidence 11
Name: Photograph of Drebber
Description: A photographic print of the engineer, Mr Enoch Drebber. It's hard to make out, but he appears to be wearing a monocle with black glass.
Evidence 12
Name: Camera
Description: The camera from around the neck of a waxwork in the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit. The actual camera that Mr Drebber had with him ten years ago when he went graverobbing. The actual camera that Mr Drebber had with him ten years ago when he went graverobbing. When the lens is extended, dark staining can be seen on the bellows.
Evidence 13
Name: Piece of Broken Glass
Description: A small fragment of very unusual and thick glass that was found in the folds of the clothing of the Professor waxwork. It would appear to be from the Crystal Tower.
Evidence 14
Name: Science Trophy
Description: A Royal Society trophy for excellence in science that was found in Mr Drebber's workshop. It's a very prestigious award for a young scientist.
Evidence 15
Name: Waxwork Head
Description: The head of the Professor waxwork that was stolen from the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit.
Evidence 16
Name: Killer's Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the mass murderer known as the Professor, who was tried and found guilty by closed trial ten years ago. [info] Condemned Prisoner 
 ***** (Redacted for confidentiality) 
 Pseudonym: The Professor 
 Ddeath by hanging confirmed at midnight, 17th June. 
 Courtney Stevens. 
Evidence 17
Name: Post-Explosion Photograph
Description: A photographic print of the experimentation stage after it was completely levelled by a time bomb. The metal floor of the stage has been blown open by the explosion. [caption] There is blood traces dripping down from the chest towards abdomen. 
Evidence 18
Name: Drebber's Contract
Description: The contract between Mr Asman and Mr Drebber detailing the terms by which they would profit from the kinesis experiment.
Evidence 19
Name: Ten-Year-Old Article
Description: A newspaper article recounting the tale of an eyewitness to the alleged 'resurrection' of the Professor from his grave on the night of his execution.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: The special exhibit in the House of Horrors is based on a rumour that shocked society in London.
Person: Tusspells
Testimony 1
Testimony: An impression of the visage was taken directly from the corpse...in accordance with Tusspells family principles.
Person: Tusspells
Testimony 2
Testimony: I enlisted the aid of the gravedigger, and created a mould for the head in the cemetery just before the interment.
Person: Tusspells
Testimony 3
Testimony: I hid myself until he gave me a signal. ...I was there for a very long time that night.
Person: Tusspells
Testimony 4
Testimony: It took me a very long time because it was before the onset of rigor mortis.
Person: Tusspells
Testimony 5
Testimony: As dawn approached, I was very worried that I could be discovered.
Person: Tusspells
Testimony 6
Testimony: I hurried to finish my work in the half hour before sunrise. Then I left as soon as the corpse was interred.
Person: Tusspells

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, so I need to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other. Let me start by going through each piece of evidence and testimony one by one to see if any of them clash.

First, looking at the evidence:

- Evidence 0: Armband. Doesn't seem relevant to the main case.
- Evidence 1: Newspaper about the Great Exhibition. Probably just background info.
- Evidence 2: Experiment Sketch. Shows positions of Crystal Tower and the machine. Maybe important for the setup.
- Evidence 3: Crossbow found under the stage, belongs to Drebber.
- Evidence 4: Piece of Green Cloth with scorch marks.
- Evidence 5: Photograph of victim showing a stab wound.
- Evidence 6: Autopsy Report says neck was broken from fall and chest stabbed.
- Evidence 7: Screwdriver with blood matching the wound.
- Evidence 8: Photograph of a balloon. The boy saw another balloon explode.
- Evidence 9: Drebber's business card with oil smear.
- Evidence 10: Wooden cage used in the experiment.
- Evidence 11: Photograph of Drebber with a monocle.
- Evidence 12: Camera with staining, linked to Drebber's past.
- Evidence 13: Broken glass from Crystal Tower.
- Evidence 14: Science Trophy in Drebber's workshop.
- Evidence 15: Waxwork Head stolen.
- Evidence 16: Autopsy Report of the Professor, who was executed.
- Evidence 17: Post-explosion photo showing blood traces.
- Evidence 18: Contract between Asman and Drebber.
- Evidence 19: Article about Professor's alleged resurrection.

Now the testimonies:

- Testimony 0: Tusspells says the exhibit is based on a shocking rumor.
- Testimony 1: Tusspells took the visage impression directly from the corpse.
- Testimony 2: Tusspells used a gravedigger to make a mold before interment.
- Testimony 3: Tusspells hid until a signal and stayed a long time.
- Testimony 4: It took a long time because rigor mortis hadn't set in yet.
- Testimony 5: Worried about being discovered as dawn approached.
- Testimony 6: Finished work in half an hour before sunrise and left after interment.

Looking for contradictions. Let's see:

Evidence 16 is the autopsy report of the Professor, who was executed and died by hanging. But Evidence 19 is a newspaper article from ten years ago about an eyewitness claiming the Professor was resurrected from his grave after execution. So, if the Professor was executed, how could he have been seen alive afterward? That seems contradictory.

Wait, but the Professor in this case is Albert Harebrayne, who is the defendant. The autopsy report in Evidence 16 refers to the executed Professor, who was a mass murderer. So, the article in Evidence 19 is about that same Professor being seen alive after execution. That would mean the executed Professor was supposedly resurrected, which contradicts the fact that he was executed and should be dead.

But wait, let's see if any testimony contradicts this. The testimonies are all from Tusspells about creating the waxwork. Testimony 2 says she made a mold before interment, which would mean she took the head before the body was buried. Testimony 4 mentions it took a long time because rigor mortis hadn't set in yet, implying the body was still fresh. Testimony 6 says she left after the corpse was interred, meaning after the burial.

But how does that relate to the evidence? Well, if Tusspells took the head before interment, that would mean the body was buried with the head missing. But in the case of the executed Professor, if he was supposed to be dead, how did someone claim to have seen him alive? Unless the waxwork was made from his actual head, which would mean the head was taken before burial, implying the Professor's body was intact but the head was used for the waxwork. However, the article says he was seen alive, which would mean he wasn't actually dead, contradicting the autopsy report.

Wait, but the contradiction isn't between testimony and evidence but between evidence 16 and 19. However, the question is about evidence and testimony contradicting each other. So perhaps I'm looking in the wrong place.

Wait, let me think again. The testimonies are all from Tusspells about how she made the waxwork. She took the head before interment, implying she had access to the corpse before burial. But if the executed Professor's head was used for the waxwork, then his body was buried without the head. But the article says he was seen alive, which would mean he wasn't actually dead, contradicting the autopsy report.

Alternatively, perhaps the contradiction is between the testimonies and the evidence about the waxwork. For example, Testimony 2 says Tusspells made a mold before interment, but Evidence 15 is the stolen waxwork head. If the waxwork was based on the actual head, then the head was taken before burial, which is what Tusspells testified. So that's consistent, not contradictory.

Wait, maybe the contradiction is between Testimony 6 and Evidence 16. Testimony 6 says Tusspells left after the corpse was interred, meaning the body was buried. But Evidence 16 says the Professor was executed and died by hanging, so his body was buried. However, the article (Evidence 19) says he was seen alive, implying he wasn't dead, which contradicts the autopsy report. But that's evidence vs evidence, not testimony vs evidence.

Alternatively, perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 4 and Evidence 16. Testimony 4 says it took a long time because rigor mortis hadn't set in yet, implying the body was fresh. Evidence 16 says the Professor was executed, so the body was dead. But that doesn't necessarily contradict.

Wait, perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 6 and Evidence 19. Testimony 6 says Tusspells left after the corpse was interred, so the body was buried. But Evidence 19 says the Professor was seen alive, implying he wasn't buried or was resurrected, which contradicts the fact that the body was buried.

But the question is about evidence and testimony contradicting each other. So perhaps the contradiction is between Evidence 16 (autopsy report of the executed Professor) and Evidence 19 (article claiming he was seen alive). But that's evidence vs evidence, not testimony vs evidence.

Wait, looking back, the testimonies are all from Tusspells about creating the waxwork. She took the head before interment, which would mean the head was removed before burial. If the waxwork head (Evidence 15) is based on the executed Professor's head, then his body was buried without the head. But the article (Evidence 19) says he was seen alive, which would mean he wasn't dead, contradicting the autopsy report (Evidence 16). But again, that's evidence vs evidence.

Alternatively, perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 2 and Evidence 15. Testimony 2 says Tusspells made a mold before interment, implying she took the head before burial. Evidence 15 is the stolen waxwork head, which would be consistent, not contradictory.

Wait, maybe the contradiction is between Testimony 6 and Evidence 19. Testimony 6 says Tusspells left after the corpse was interred, so the body was buried. But Evidence 19 says the Professor was seen alive, implying he wasn't dead, which contradicts the fact that he was executed and buried.

But the question is to find a pair where evidence and testimony contradict each other. So perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 6 and Evidence 19. Testimony 6 says Tusspells left after the corpse was interred, implying the body was buried. Evidence 19 says the Professor was seen alive, implying he wasn't dead, which contradicts the fact that he was executed and buried.

Alternatively, perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 4 and Evidence 16. Testimony 4 says it took a long time because rigor mortis hadn't set in yet, implying the body was fresh. Evidence 16 says the Professor was executed, so the body was dead. But that's consistent, not contradictory.

Wait, maybe the contradiction is between Testimony 2 and Evidence 15. Testimony 2 says Tusspells made a mold before interment, implying she took the head before burial. Evidence 15 is the stolen waxwork head, which would be consistent, not contradictory.

Alternatively, perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 6 and Evidence 19. Testimony 6 says Tusspells left after the corpse was interred, so the body was buried. But Evidence 19 says the Professor was seen alive, implying he wasn't dead, which contradicts the fact that he was executed and buried.

Wait, but the question is about evidence and testimony, not evidence and evidence. So perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 6 and Evidence 19. Testimony 6 says Tusspells left after the corpse was interred, implying the body was buried. Evidence 19 says the Professor was seen alive, implying he wasn't dead, which contradicts the fact that he was executed and buried.

But wait, the executed Professor's body was buried, so how could he be seen alive? That's the contradiction.

So, the pair would be Evidence 19 and Testimony 6. Because Testimony 6 says the corpse was interred (buried), implying the Professor was dead and buried. But Evidence 19 says he was seen alive, implying he wasn't dead, which contradicts.

Alternatively, perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 6 and Evidence 16. Testimony 6 says Tusspells left after the corpse was interred, implying the body was buried. Evidence 16 says the Professor was executed and died by hanging, so the body was buried. But that's consistent, not contradictory.

Wait, perhaps I'm overcomplicating this. Let me look for any testimony that directly contradicts an evidence.

Looking at the testimonies, they all relate to Tusspells creating the waxwork. The only evidence that relates to the waxwork is Evidence 15 (stolen head) and Evidence 12 (camera with staining). But none of the testimonies directly contradict these.

Wait, perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 4 and Evidence 6. Testimony 4 says it took a long time because rigor mortis hadn't set in yet, implying the body was fresh. Evidence 6 says the victim's neck was broken from a fall and chest stabbed, which is about the victim Odie Asman, not the executed Professor. So that's not a contradiction.

Alternatively, perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 5 and Evidence 6. Testimony 5 says Tusspells was worried about being discovered as dawn approached. Evidence 6 is the autopsy report of Asman, which doesn't relate directly.

Wait, perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 6 and Evidence 19. Testimony 6 says Tusspells left after the corpse was interred, implying the body was buried. Evidence 19 says the Professor was seen alive, implying he wasn't dead, which contradicts the fact that he was executed and buried.

So, the pair would be Evidence 19 and Testimony 6. Because Testimony 6 says the corpse was interred (buried), implying the Professor was dead. Evidence 19 says he was seen alive, implying he wasn't dead, which contradicts.

Alternatively, perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 2 and Evidence 15. Testimony 2 says Tusspells made a mold before interment, implying she took the head before burial. Evidence 15 is the stolen waxwork head, which would be consistent, not contradictory.

Wait, but the question is to find a pair where evidence and testimony contradict each other. So perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 6 and Evidence 19. Testimony 6 says the corpse was interred, implying the Professor was dead. Evidence 19 says he was seen alive, implying he wasn't dead, which contradicts.

Alternatively, perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 4 and Evidence 16. Testimony 4 says it took a long time because rigor mortis hadn't set in yet, implying the body was fresh. Evidence 16 says the Professor was executed, so the body was dead. But that's consistent, not contradictory.

Wait, perhaps the contradiction is between Testimony 6 and Evidence 19. Testimony 6 says Tusspells left after the corpse was interred, implying the body was buried. Evidence 19 says the Professor was seen alive, implying he wasn't dead, which contradicts the fact that he was executed and buried.

Yes, that makes sense. So the pair would be Evidence 19 and Testimony 6.
</think>

Testimony 0
Testimony: The reason I was in Lowgate Cemetery at all ten years ago was for...a spot of moonlighting, shall we say?
Person: Drebber
Testimony 1
Testimony: Yes, the illustration in that newspaper article was based on what I witnessed that night.
Person: Drebber
Testimony 2
Testimony: Thinking back now, I realise that I never actually saw the Professor at all, though.
Person: Drebber
Testimony 3
Testimony: What I in fact witnessed, was a fellow graverobber at work.
Person: Drebber
Testimony 4
Testimony: There was no gunshot from behind me at all. Nor any splattering blood.
Person: Drebber
Testimony 5
Testimony: Soon afterwards, I was visited by a young woman who sculpted a model of me from wax.
Person: Drebber
Testimony 6
Testimony: Then I gave up on my dream of becoming a scientist. And it was all because of that newspaper article.
Person: Drebber

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, so I need to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let me go through the process step by step.

First, I'll look at the testimonies provided. Each testimony is given by Enoch Drebber, and they all relate to events ten years ago, specifically around the time of the Professor's execution and the subsequent events.

Looking at the testimonies:

- Testimony 0: Drebber was moonlighting in Lowgate Cemetery.
- Testimony 1: The newspaper article's illustration was based on what he witnessed.
- Testimony 2: He never actually saw the Professor.
- Testimony 3: He witnessed a fellow graverobber.
- Testimony 4: There was no gunshot or blood splattering.
- Testimony 5: A young woman sculpted a wax model of him.
- Testimony 6: He gave up being a scientist because of the article.

Now, looking at the evidence, especially the Ten-Year-Old Article (Evidence 19). It mentions an eyewitness account of the Professor's supposed resurrection. The article would imply that someone saw the Professor come back to life, which would include elements like a gunshot or blood splattering, as those are typical in such dramatic events.

But in Testimony 4, Drebber explicitly states that there was no gunshot from behind him and no blood splattering. This directly contradicts the article's account, which probably described such events as part of the resurrection story. So if the article says there was a gunshot and blood, but Drebber says there wasn't, that's a clear contradiction.

I should also check if any other evidence might contradict testimonies. For example, Evidence 12 mentions a camera with staining, which might tie into Testimony 5 about the wax model. But the main contradiction seems to be between Testimony 4 and Evidence 19.

So the pair that contradicts is Evidence 19 and Testimony 4.
</think>

Character 5
Name: Albert Harebrayne
Description: A scientist who invented a machine to demonstrate super-high-voltage instantaneous kinesis. However, it exploded in use, and he is now accused of murder.↳A scientist who invented a machine to demonstrate super-high-voltage instantaneous kinesis. He's the defendant of this case and a friend to Lord van Zieks, apparently.
Character 6
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 7
Name: Masked Man
Description: An apprentice of Lord van Zieks whose face is always covered by a mask. He has the air of a completely unassailable man.
Character 8
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A mostly reformed pickpocket who's now a self-appointed 'detective inspector'. She's really making waves in her new apprenticeship.
Character 9
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: The detective inspector in charge of Scotland Yard's investigation of the case. He's stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 10
Name: Esmeralda Tusspells
Description: The proprietress of the Madame Tusspells Museum of Waxwork and the latest in a line of artisans privy to the secret Tusspells technique of capturing a perfect likeness.
Character 11
Name: Balthazar Lune
Description: The impresario of short pleasure voyages in flying balloons. The balloons above the experimentation state all belonged to this man.
Character 12
Name: Bohemian Boy
Description: A young boy who came to London to visit the Great Exhibition. His real name is Wilhelm Gottsreich Sigismond Ormstein.↳A young prince from the royal family of Bohemia with an excessively long name. He witnessed the explosion at the Great Exhibition.
Character 13
Name: Courtney Sithe
Description: Scotland Yard coroner, leader of the Forensic Investigation Team and one of Lord Stronghart's most trusted allies.
Character 14
Name: Enoch Drebber
Description: A trickster who seems to be both an engineer and a magician. He constructed the machine for Professor Harebrayne's demonstration.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Great Exhibition Newspaper
Description: A newspaper containing various articles about the world-leading science and technology on show at the Great Exhibition being held in London.
Evidence 2
Name: Experiment Sketch
Description: A diagram showing the relative positions of the Crystal Tower and Professor Harebrayne's machine that exploded. 
Evidence 3
Name: Mysterious Contraption → Crossbow
Description: A very curious device found behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds, almost as if it had been hidden there deliberately. A weapon found hidden behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. It turns out that it's a folding crossbow. A crossbow found hidden behind a tree under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. It belongs to Mr Enoch Drebber.
Evidence 4
Name: Piece of Green Cloth
Description: A torn piece of canvas-like material backed with rubber that was found under the experimentation stage at the exhibition grounds. There are scorch marks at the edges.
Evidence 5
Name: Photograph of the Victim
Description: A photographic print of the victim taken after he had ostensibly been 'beamed' to the Crystal Tower. It shows an apparent stab wound to the chest.
Evidence 6
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the victim, Mr Asman. His neck was broken from the impact of a violent fall and he was stabbed in the chest with a sharp object.
Evidence 7
Name: Screwdriver
Description: Professor Harebrayne's trusty screwdriver that he's named 'Andrew'. There are traces of blood at the tip and it matches the shape of the victim's wound. A metal screwdriver that was found poking through the grille in the base of what remains of the kinesis machine. It has a very distinctive handle.
Evidence 8
Name: Photograph of the Balloon
Description: A photograph taken by Gotts whilst he was riding in a balloon. It shows another balloon that he claims was green and exploded moments after he took this shot.
Evidence 9
Name: Drebber's Card
Description: Mr Enoch Drebber's business card, though it shows only the man's name. There is no address. Mr Enoch Drebber's business card, which lists no address for the man. There is a smear of machine oil on the reverse.
Evidence 10
Name: Wooden 'Birdcage'
Description: The wooden cage that was used for Professor Harebrayne's experiment. This cage, with the victim inside, crashed down into the Crystal Tower. The wooden cage that was used for the demonstration. It crashed down, with the victim inside, into the Crystal Tower causing damage to its base.
Evidence 11
Name: Photograph of Drebber
Description: A photographic print of the engineer, Mr Enoch Drebber. It's hard to make out, but he appears to be wearing a monocle with black glass.
Evidence 12
Name: Camera
Description: The camera from around the neck of a waxwork in the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit. The actual camera that Mr Drebber had with him ten years ago when he went graverobbing. The actual camera that Mr Drebber had with him ten years ago when he went graverobbing. When the lens is extended, dark staining can be seen on the bellows.
Evidence 13
Name: Piece of Broken Glass
Description: A small fragment of very unusual and thick glass that was found in the folds of the clothing of the Professor waxwork. It would appear to be from the Crystal Tower.
Evidence 14
Name: Science Trophy
Description: A Royal Society trophy for excellence in science that was found in Mr Drebber's workshop. It's a very prestigious award for a young scientist.
Evidence 15
Name: Waxwork Head
Description: The head of the Professor waxwork that was stolen from the Madame Tusspells Special Exhibit.
Evidence 16
Name: Killer's Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the mass murderer known as the Professor, who was tried and found guilty by closed trial ten years ago. [info] Condemned Prisoner 
 ***** (Redacted for confidentiality) 
 Pseudonym: The Professor 
 Ddeath by hanging confirmed at midnight, 17th June. 
 Courtney Stevens. 
Evidence 17
Name: Post-Explosion Photograph
Description: A photographic print of the experimentation stage after it was completely levelled by a time bomb. The metal floor of the stage has been blown open by the explosion. [caption] There is blood traces dripping down from the chest towards abdomen. 
Evidence 18
Name: Drebber's Contract
Description: The contract between Mr Asman and Mr Drebber detailing the terms by which they would profit from the kinesis experiment.
Evidence 19
Name: Ten-Year-Old Article
Description: A newspaper article recounting the tale of an eyewitness to the alleged 'resurrection' of the Professor from his grave on the night of his execution.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: It all began at the scene when I saw the waxwork and the note tucked inside its jacket.
Person: Sithe
Testimony 1
Testimony: The actual body of the victim, as indicated in the note's instructions, was beneath the experimentation stage.
Person: Sithe
Testimony 2
Testimony: The body had to be 'arranged' in certain ways to implicate the defendant...which was my job.
Person: Sithe
Testimony 3
Testimony: The actual cause of death was the neck trauma Asman suffered from the thirty-foot fall.
Person: Sithe
Testimony 4
Testimony: I stood over the victim's corpse where it lay in the toppled cage and plunged the screwdriver into the chest.
Person: Sithe
Testimony 5
Testimony: I enlisted the help of the entire Forensic Investigation Team to dress the scene appropriately.
Person: Sithe
Testimony 6
Testimony: The truth about the execution ten years ago is a state secret of the highest level. I had to protect it.
Person: Sithe

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's try to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other here. So, I've got a bunch of characters, evidences, and testimonies listed. The goal is to find a pair where one evidence and one testimony contradict each other.

Looking at the evidences, Evidence 10 describes the wooden cage crashing down into the Crystal Tower with the victim inside. So that aligns with her testimony about the body being beneath the stage.

Not necessarily yet.

Testimony 3: She states that the actual cause of death was neck trauma from a thirty-foot fall. Looking at Evidence 6, the autopsy report confirms that Asman's neck was broken from a violent fall and he was stabbed. So this testimony aligns with the evidence, not contradicting it.

Testimony 4: She claims she stood over the victim's corpse and plunged the screwdriver into the chest. Now, Evidence 7 is the screwdriver with blood traces matching the wound. If Sithe used this screwdriver, that would mean she was the one who caused the stab wound. But wait, the victim's death was from a fall, so the stabbing might have been a setup. However, if Sithe says she did it, that could conflict with the idea that the stabbing was part of the arrangement rather than the actual cause of death.

Wait, the autopsy report (Evidence 6) says the victim was stabbed, but the cause of death was the neck trauma. So the stabbing was probably a red herring. If Sithe admits to stabbing him, that might contradict the fact that the stabbing wasn't the cause of death, but it's more about who did it rather than the cause of death. So maybe that's not a contradiction.

Testimony 5: She enlisted the help of the entire Forensic Investigation Team to dress the scene. This doesn't directly contradict any evidence but suggests a conspiracy.

Testimony 6: She says the truth about the execution ten years ago is a state secret and she had to protect it. This might relate to Evidence 19, the ten-year-old article about the Professor's alleged resurrection. If she's protecting the secret, maybe the article's claims are false, but I'm not sure if that's a direct contradiction.

Now, looking back, the main point of contradiction might be between Testimony 4 and Evidence 7. Sithe says she used the screwdriver to stab the victim, but the autopsy report (Evidence 6) says the stabbing was with a sharp object, which could be the screwdriver. However, the cause of death was the fall, so the stabbing was just a setup. This might not be a contradiction but more of a setup detail.

Wait, another angle: Evidence 7 says the screwdriver was found poking through the grille in the base of the machine. If Sithe used it to stab the victim, then the screwdriver would have been at the scene, which aligns with Evidence 7. So maybe no contradiction there.

Looking again, maybe Testimony 4 and Evidence 7 don't contradict, but perhaps another pair does. Let me check other testimonies and evidences.

Looking at Evidence 17: Post-Explosion Photograph shows blood traces from the chest towards the abdomen. Testimony 4 says she stabbed the victim in the chest. So the photograph supports the stabbing, which aligns with her testimony.

Hmm, maybe I'm overcomplicating. Let me look for a direct contradiction. Perhaps Testimony 4 and Evidence 7? If Sithe says she used the screwdriver to stab the victim, but Evidence 7 says the screwdriver was found in the machine's base, maybe that's a setup. But that doesn't necessarily contradict; it just shows where the screwdriver was found after the stabbing.

Alternatively, maybe Testimony 6 and Evidence 19. Testimony 6 says the truth is a state secret, implying the article (Evidence 19) might be false. But the article is about an eyewitness to the Professor's resurrection, which might not directly relate to Sithe's actions in this case. So perhaps not a contradiction.

Wait, another angle: Evidence 16 is the Killer's Autopsy Report from ten years ago, which mentions the Professor's execution. Testimony 6 mentions protecting the secret about the execution. If the article (Evidence 19) claims the Professor resurrected, but the autopsy report says he died by hanging, then the article's claim contradicts the autopsy report. So Evidence 19 and Evidence 16 contradict each other, but the question is about evidence and testimony.

Wait, the user is asking for one pair of evidence and testimony that contradict each other. So maybe Evidence 19 (the article) and Testimony 6 (Sithe protecting the execution secret). If the article claims the Professor came back, but Sithe says the truth is a secret, implying he didn't, then they contradict.

Alternatively, Testimony 6 says the truth is a state secret, meaning the article's claim is false. So Testimony 6 contradicts Evidence 19.

But the user wants one pair, so maybe {"evidence": 19, "testimony": 6}.

Wait, but in the previous interaction, the user provided a similar setup and I answered {"evidence": 19, "testimony": 4}. Now, in this new setup, the testimonies are from Sithe, not Drebber. So I need to adjust.

Looking at the current testimonies, Testimony 6 is about protecting the execution secret, which might relate to the article (Evidence 19) claiming a resurrection. So if Sithe says the truth is a secret, implying the article is false, then they contradict.

Alternatively, maybe another pair. Let me check all possibilities again.

Another possible contradiction: Testimony 4 says Sithe stabbed the victim with the screwdriver, but Evidence 7 says the screwdriver was found in the machine's base. If Sithe used it, then it would have been at the scene, which aligns, not contradicts.

Wait, maybe Testimony 5 says she enlisted the Forensic Investigation Team, but Evidence 10 describes the cage crashing down. If the team dressed the scene, maybe they made it look like the cage fell, but the actual cause was the explosion. But that's more about the setup than a direct contradiction.
